title: RODI: A Benchmark for Automatic Mapping Generation in Relational-to-Ontology Data Integration
segmentation: Welcome everyone.
I'm Krista Finkel with fluid operations, and I'm presenting roadie, which, as a benchmark about measuring the quality of automatically generated mappings between relational databases and ontologies.
This is a joint effort, together with several academic partners.
So in our DB to RDF mappings that is in mappings between relational databases and RDF's and ontologies.

You apparently have a relational database as a source at the bottom, which stores information in relational that is tabular format and you need to transform them up to your RDF database in some ontological format if you want to use generated mappings.
A system comes into play that generates those mappings actually for you, so you can get going.
Usually what you're having is some part of the ontology already in place.
That's a target requirement or target ontology.
A target T box.
More precisely, a schema that you have to map to.
This can be a common domain ontology that's just widely used.
This can also be some ontology with which has just been engineered for the purpose.
After some requirements, in fewer cases, that could be that you just started off with.
One of your data sources and created an ontology for that by bootstrapping manual adjustments and then all of the others have to learn to that.
In another case, in the end you need mappings and what you really want to do.
With your target ontology as to.
Raise queries against it like say give me all the offers here in my ontology.
And then what you expect your mappings to do for you is to fill the ontology, fill the tee box with additional ebox facts in such a way that that query actually answers.
So mapping quality in terms of utility as most and foremost about whether the queries that you can run over ontologies, the queries that you care about.
Answer With exactly the results that you would expect.
In our case, that's a result set where all the authors from the database are in the result set of the query.
Asking for authors phrased over the ontology, but similarly nothing else which was not in the original database.
And to benchmark that to test that this is actually what we're doing.
So we have a source database of target ontology and a mapping generating system which we test which generates mappings.

And then we start to ask queries many simple queries over over the target Ontology and sparkle to test individual aspects of the schema as we're focusing on different challenges of the mapping generation.
And.
Then we have another query and equivalent query a corresponding query an SQL which we run at the same time over the original source database and check whether their result sets compare.

With relation to an equivalence metric which we have defined in such a way that it can cope with the fact that well, different mapping generating systems will create different entity, your eyes for the same entity.
But apparently they they should create the same facts with literals and also the same number of entities for each type.

So what's the challenges here for the mapping systems tested, and especially what other challenges an that are specific to the Inter model mapping gap to the problem of mapping relational databases from a relational model to an ontology model as opposed to intra model mapping such as in relational schema mapping ontology alignment?

So at the most basic challenges already, start with the most basic schemas and ontologies you could get if you look at something as simple as you have authors who write papers that are accepted, them some conferences which take place in some cities, but the authors are also living in some other cities.
And even if you take the specification behind that and create a relational schema for the exact same specification, even using the same identifiers.
You
Come up with something which is largely similar but still has inherent structural differences.
So for instance, we have one separate table for each other concepts, authors, papers and so on.
But we do also have a dedicated table for the rights property for the property of authors writing papers.
And that's because this relation, this particular relation is an antonym relations, so paper is usually written by several authors, but authors overtime as a write lots of papers.
And this in in a relational schema with normalization, this requires a separate table, while all of the other properties you're having here are not.
Enter them so they do not require their dedicated tables are just hidden somewhere in an attribute within one particular table in form of a foreign key typically.
Then there's naming again, even if we are working with the exact same specification and start with the exact same language.
Even under this very, very strict assumption, we would still end up with different identifiers because what people are typically doing in ontologies versus relational databases.
To be somehow different.
So in databases yet and a lot more to using abbreviations here you would use plural rather than singular for concepts you would often use technical abbreviations like in the case of that property.
Here relating authors to the city they live in.
You say something like living in an ontology.

The foreign key relating the two tables for a database designer is usually just the foreign key though the key the ID of the city, so it would be city ID are here just abbreviated again see ID and so on.
Um?
Then come the real challenges.
Normalization might be bad enough in many cases.
Because you have it quite a lot, it's inherent to the whole thing, but then often enough people also denormalized their scheme again to some degree.
This can happen for several reasons, lazy schema design being one.
Asian overtime being another, but it's also done a lot on purpose.
Say to optimize the physical schema to certain query workloads to make it perform better on that.

But no matter what the reasons what you're getting in the end is a table which essentially includes several concepts and you have to deal with that and find mappings that extract those difference concepts from one single table.
There are other such advanced challenges, like if you have no or few foreign keys, referential constraints.

If those are missing or you just have to view then you don't get any explicit hint on where to join your tables to connect them on some properties, but you still will have to join them even without those hands to get your properties right.
That's also very particular challenge, which is a little more advanced.
Then come class hierarchies.
You have them everywhere that a very fundamental modeling primitive in general.
Of course, at a conceptual level you also have them when you're constructing relational databases in ERER diagrams, for example.
But what you do not have?
As a primitive to model that you have that and ontologies like a subclass off property which basically gives you axioms like saying North or is a subtype of a person an.
Similarly revenue is 2 in the relational database.
On the other hand, you still have to model that somehow, but you don't have a modeling parameter and stab.
You have different design patterns that different database architects used to different degrees.
So some of those are better for certain characteristics of the data, but it's also largely a matter of taste.
The first of those options which has been identified in the literature as a fairly widely used pattern.
Anne, it's.

Putting several concepts together in one table again, so in our case, then you have all the persons and one table and out of their table includes all the specific attributes of all the specific subtypes and you just leave those values.
Those attributes empty for special subclasses which do not have that attribute.
So you put another value there.
Then optionally you may have a type column or type ID column or some role flex.
That identify what exact type it is.
You may or may not have that, and that's a pattern which we see a lot in practice.
Second option, you just put all the miss specific subclasses in different tables and forget about the parent class, which may not seem obvious from ontology perspective.

For instance, you know that there are a lot of persons who are neither authors nor reviews in this example, but in a relational database, which is usually designed for just one application scenario, this may make perfect sense that this is basically all the persons.
This is not too hard to get for mappings unless you have some redundancy in there which is.
Also that's bad practice, but we still see it.
Third option, which is the closest to what we're having in ontologies.
You have one table for each of these app and super classes, so we have a table for persons and a table for authors and a table for revelers, each with their specific attributes.
And then you can join them together.
Um, the thing?
Why our impression that there are no empiric numbers as far as I know?
But to our impression, this pattern isn't so widely used for probably obvious, practical reasons, because if you do that, it's relatively hard to handle in a relational database.
You usually don't have to do it so so you don't do it.
It's harder to create if you get all those foreign keys right to do your Giants, then it's also harder to maintain because updates have to consider all the.
Dependencies you are building them even if you query it, you have to do more Giants which you do not like to do, which may even in some cases impact performance.
So those are all reasons why this isn't used to match.
OK, but

Among all those challenges, all those challenges are among things that are specific to mapping from relational databases to ontologies, and that's what we're focusing on in the roadie benchmark, and have built benchmark Suit to test those challenges in.
So for the framework, of course we're testing different systems and.
Basic idea was that we're having ontologies, databases and query tests on those, and our main tests are set out and the conference domain because it's well understood.

Also, our challenges are mostly structural and inherent to the model, so we could mostly test that in each and every domain and we're having synthetic databases that we create systematically in a way to control the different challenges and have controlled settings that focus on different challenges.

We've taken 3 ontologies from the conference domain from the API conference track and added this synthetic databases here by first translating in a principled manner, basically approximating an ER diagram from the ontology an then implementing affecting database by the book from that, and then we introduce different modifications in terms of the structure of the schema, normalization, denormalization, things like that.
In addition, the benchmark framework is extensible.
So you can add additional database and ontology path with corresponding query tasks to evaluate on different domains or real world query workloads.
That's also something we want to do in the future to add actual domain data and actual queries elicited from actual user requirements.
To test our system would perform on that.
You can do that for asthma.
In domains as you like.
Of course, the benchmark suit is publicly available.
You can go to our website, downloaded an it's a benchmark.
We would be happy of course to see people using it reporting numbers on their setups or systems.
We are also planning to do a more intense, a deeper and broader evaluation in the future, so would be great to also get numbers from others on that.
Who might even prove our poor results that we got so far wrong?
Talking about which we also ran an initial evaluation on a few systems and got a few numbers so.
What we did here and assistance were using and evaluating in this first run.
An optics Botox bootstrapper mapping bootstrapper, which acts in a 2 step fashion.
First, they create an initial ontology for a database without any respect for the original target ontology.

This follows basically W 3C's direct mapping and then they're adding some additional axioms which that basically guessing an and then they apply ontology alignment to get to the actual target ontology.
Then there's our own internal Prototype Inc Map which uses a direct mapping approach.
This direct mapping approach uses a simplified and unified mapping graph to directly relate the relational database to the target ontology.
And we tried two more setups which are also two step involving lock map as an ontology aligner.
And first create different kinds of initial mappings.
There's mirror which is related to morph, which is a very new and very promising approach to create a richer and more sophisticated and natural ontology.
But it's also very new system with still some technical shortcomings and as a baseline, basically on top, which has a plugin that also creates initial mappings.
And which is pretty straightforward.
And then we also perform ontology alignment.
Um, so looking at numbers and at the first glance you will see that they are not exactly mind blowing.
So what you're seeing here is essentially averaged.
Have measures, so we're having query tests, individual query tests as I said, and on each of those we have defined local precision and recall.
We have thousands of query tasks for each scenario that we're testing.
So then we are averaging the difference costs over the different query tests.
And intuitively you can think of those calls as the percentage of tests that worked.
For that particular scenario, an for the particular system.
Looking a bit on who's winning where so.
Inc Maps performing best on two types of scenarios on the CMT Ontology, and that's the basic renamed scenarios, so that's just the basic translation normalization of the schema.
So an author book translation with changed identifiers.
And structured is when we introduce a mix of different hierarchy and other patterns as would be typical in a relational database out there.
But Inc map only only excels there in those two cases, both with the CMT Ontology, which is one of the three conference ontologies we've been using.
